title: Can we just reduce Doran's shield cost by 50
body: So that we can get an extra HP pot to survive those heavy poke lanes.

replies.body:
This. 

The main reason I never take D-Shield is because literally any start gives you much more EHP via potions, stats, as well as many of them building into something else. 

Even {{item:1028}} is a better start than D-Shield.
I wouldn't take Ruby Crystal over DS unless you are expecting to back 2.5 minutes into trading. See my post below if you care for the maths.

Ruby isn't a good start, but its still better than D-Shield. 

You should basically never take D-shield unless you're vs Vlad and plan on getting an early Hexdrinker or Cowl.

Vlad's about the only champion whose damage doesn't significantly outscale D-Shield almost immediately. He has to be extremely aggressive with autos (which are some of the weakest in the game, thus hit hardest by D-Shield, fyi) to do anything significant to your health. You're basically immune to him after you grab an MR item with it. 

Any other case? **Don't buy D-shield.**

Doran Shield's passive health regen gives you more effective health in lane than Ruby Crystal and its extra Health pot as long as you are able to stay in lane long enough to utilize it. Long story short, Doran's Shield is a free Health pot in health regeneration every 2 minutes, and unless you're picking Darius into Jayce you can expect to stay in lane long enough to take advantage of that free health.

Honestly the only reason people think Doran's Shield is a bad item is because its passive is so niche. If it gave you flat health instead of a crummy passive component it would be the better choice for effective health in lane a majority of the time.

One thing you're forgeting about is the opportunity cost of D-shield. When you buy a Ruby you are 400 gold into your next item. This means you can afford to back early. You want to back around 800 gold with a Ruby for Bramby+2 pots. That same back would be 1200 if you started with D-shield.

Something to keep in mind is that health regeneration isn't stored like flat HP or potions in your inventory. The only time the health regen gives you effective health is when you're below max, so it either encourages being very aggressive or only works in a lane where the enemy is aggressive. A passive-passive bro lane will never have Doran's shield be good (except maybe with jg ganks constantly?) and an aggressive vs aggressive lane tends to favor other options like Doran's blade or corrupting.

Being poked and trading with your lane opponent are two different things. You don't have to be very aggressive to take damage from your lane opponent, and if you end up on the wrong side of a trade, you won't have the problem of being full health and missing health regen for a while. You make it sound like health regen only works when you are low on health, but being low on health and not being max health are not the same thing, and you only have to be just below max health for health regen to work.

Doran's Shield is for aggressive vs passive lanes; it's the best option that a passive laner has to maximize effective HP against an aggressive poke lane. Think about matchups like an immobile juggernaut versus a lane opponent with ranged poke. The juggernaut just needs to hold out and pick up cs until their lane opponent makes a mistake that they can capitalize on, but will hardly be at max health for very long because of their lane opponent's ranged attacks and spells. I main Darius, and I never take anything but Doran's Shield against champions like Gnar or Teemo; I won't be trading often, but I'll be under max health at all times so I can make the most of DS's health regen.

Math it out and Doran's Shield passes Ruby Crystal in terms of extra health in lane after 3 minutes of health regen, and that is not including the damage blocked from its passive which provides the equivalent of 8 health every time you are hit by a basic attack, not only from your lane opponent but also from minions as well.

The advantage of taking the Ruby Crystal is that you build it into something else and thus you have 220 extra gold over Doran's, but unless you are forced to back 2.5 minutes into trading the Doran's Shield pulls more weight.

Except {{item:1055}} gives as much health and lifesteal, which is better for AD champs because the shield is running on 1.2 HP per second. With lifesteal you can get 2 HP per second if you constantly auto attack. The passive of shield is so bad against champs with any aoe damage, such as {{champion:84}} {{champion:1}} {{champion:420}} {{champion:245}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:150}} {{champion:157}} if he uses EQ, etc. It's supposed to encourage you to trade but by doing that you're constantly losing more HP than you regen.

Basic attacking that frequently means that you're pushing your lane--which, as a passive laner, is definitely not what you want to be doing. Top it off with the fact that D. Shield healing is active 100% of the time without having to get into poke range and you got yourself the better choice for passive laners especially ones that don't need the AD.
Chances are that if you're considering a shield you don't have the lane presence to trade or sit there constantly auto attacking.
If someone comes up to auto you, at least auto back and kite while you run. They have to run past your minions, which do a lot early game.

>  its passive which provides the equivalent of 8 health every time you are hit by a basic attack

.

> The damage reduction is calculated before armor and percentage damage reduction benefits are taken into account.

[source!](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Doran's_Shield)

This means that Vladimir, who basic attacks for 52 damage at level 1 or uses Q for 75 damage (Let's say +5 from 12 AP).

Doran's Shield reduces that to 44 damage, respectively 72 damage.

Let's say your resistances are a clean 25% each. (Not entirely accurate, but increased a bit for ease of maths.)

44 x 0.75 = 33 damage is what you receive.
72 x 0.75 = 54 damage is what you receive.

WITHOUT Doran's Shield, you'd take

52 x 0.75 = 39 damage
80 x 0.75 = 60 damage

Effectively, Doran's Shield's only reduced the damage by 6, not 8, because it applies before armour reduction takes place.

The more you know.

And as you already mentioned, you already invested 400 gold into hitting your power spike and since time is the essence, there's a major difference between getting sunfire in 10min than in 14min.

Also, Shield doesnt block 8 damage as advertise and it also doesnt block minion damage either. It blocks damage before resistances is applied rather than after. > I'll put my main points in sections for ease of read as to why Shield is objectionably the worst item of the Doran set and has been for the past few seasons. Im only comparing Doran's set because listing out why practically using any other starting sets over Shield are better will make the post way too long. Trying to keep it short and sweet as possible.
> 
> Shield Cost and gold efficient:
> As it currently stands, Shield costs 450 gold while only being is 95.41% gold efficient, without its unique passive. To put it in contrast, Blade is 134.63% gold efficient and Ring is is 184.06% gold efficient even without its passive mana restore on kill. While at the same time, Ring is also the cheapest of the three allowing you to buy two health pots instead of one. In a numbers perspective, Shield is 38.92% less efficient than Blade and 88.65% less efficient than Ring. For a clearer perspective..
> 
> Doran's Ring = 736 gold value
> Doran's Blade = 605
> Doran's Shield = 429
> 
> With pots included
> Ring + 2 = 836
> Blade + 1 = 655
> Shield + 1 = 479
> 
> Block Passive
> Not only Shield provides the worst stats in gold value and but it does not even truly block 8 damage as advertised as it blocks damage before resistances is calculated rather than after. Meaning the actual damage blocked will always be less than 8. It is also the only item in the game that gains less value from it's block passive the more resistances you gain throughout the game. On top of that, the block passive is not only unique but it is also so restrictive that the majority of the time it won't see use as area of effect damage is the primary source of damage.
> 
> HP Regen
> The heath regeneration also discourages from buying shield because of it's flat 6hp regen per 5 seconds (1.2hp per second) and the worst part of it is that it doesnt scale. I say this because over 95% of the champion roster's health regen exceeds 6 at level 3 meaning that you will gain more value from just buying two rejuvenation beads in addition to having three health pots. To further my case, 98 out of 134 (73%) champs has or exceeds Shield's regen passive at level 1.

Even making Shield cheaper allowing 2 pots will still not make it a worth while item in any form.

For the record, I do think the Doran's Shield is weak, but I don't think it's useless. On one hand, if its crummy passive were replaced with increases to its base stats, it would be in a much better place than it is, but it is still a good pick in poke lanes because of it's health regen, and you definitely shouldn't be taking Ruby Crystal instead.

Doran's Shield's cost shouldn't be reduced; they just need to cannibalize its block passive and give people the stats they really want.

There's a big difference between a champion having something and an item having something.

A champion having a specific ability means it can be balanced strictly around the champion, and how good it is on said champion.

An item with a specific ability has to be balanced for the entire roster to use.

While I'm not going to argue whether or not a Doran's Ring that restores health instead of mana is just redundant (I mean Doran's Blade), but you can't say champion abilities would be good ideas as items.
